I usually do some short forming like; MBI (MultibootISO) as well as Parted Magic (PM) which you find is named in its LZ compressed and zipped extension as pmagicXX. I re-found some info about PMagic, that it has a simple way of installing new programs you add to the Live CD. Simply drop the new package in the live folder directory and it automatically installs them at boot ![:hyper:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/hyper.gif) Sorry, I didn't mean to ruffle your feathers you big wonk :smile: Now, if I could just find a way to type much less and not have to use a mouse at all!
c/o: [http://partedmagic.c...g-programs.html](http://partedmagic.com/documentation/122-adding-programs.html "External link") Parted Magic is not exactly Slackware based, but the main tool chain was compiled on Slackware. \*shrug\* If you are using the USB version the packages can be simply copied to /pmagic/pmodules. Pmagic will automatically load this directory everytime, simplifying custom package loading. But then it seems contradictory in going on to say that you may, or do, need to remaster the iso... nevermind. I think the ending spells it out better... it just depends on how you have it loaded to your (in my case) Thumbdrive or.... Pendrive, Flashdrive. I mean USB Flashdrive Memory device. continuing..... If you would like to add programs your best bet is to use TGZ packages from Slackware 13.x. You can also use DEB files, but Parted Magic doesn't make any attempt to resolve dependencies. Intall XZ for Linux if your distro doesn't already have it. The txz archives allow for a file format that easily works with Parted Magic.
For this example we will make a txz module for cramfs. Create a directory that will be the mock /usr. mkdir -p fake_usr/sbin cp /sbin/mkcramfs fake_usr/sbin cd fake_usr tar cvJf ../cramfs.txz \* And it also states again that these packages are automatically loaded... Now copy the cramfs.txz package to the pmodules directory on the Parted Magic media. Obviously if you're using the LiveCD the iso must be remastered and reburned. Using the USB version you can just copy it to the pmodules directory. Parted Magic automatically unloads all \*txz packages in pmodules, so no further configuration is needed. What was the point of this input? \*shrug\* Did i mention how well it was put together for the un-intelligible Tech head? That don't like rodents? BTW wonk, did you get your hug today :smile: - Z

I thought I would add some findings to this thread since its still high on the list with quite a few views... If I could of had this info earlier it would of saved a lot of time deciphering my most favored people here ![<_<](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/dry.png)  

These are some basics and advanced on using and modifying the Menu.lst that you find on your chosen device once you have MBI install syslinux/GrubDos/Grub4Dos (I give up trying to keep track of which is which) but you get the point...  

Mind that most of these entries are with the ISO in its ISO state and simply dropped on the root of the drive! If you extract your ISO to a folder these settings will likely not work ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)  

If you add them to a folder on your chosen device you will need to edit the paths appropriately. As you will see I have left some notes at the beginning of some menu entries. Anything with a "#" preceeding the line is not parsed.  

\<--- --- -- Copy and paste any or all from below this line -- Do Not Copy This Line --- ---\>  
default 0  
timeout 99  
color NORMAL HIGHLIGHT HELPTEXT HEADING  
splashimage=/splash.xpm.gz  
foreground=FFFFFF  
background=000000  

title ___________________________ ( - Zedd's Custom PNY - ) ______________________________  
root  

# Works great for quick access to your UFD but only supports 8.3 format e.g. boot-land.net = boot-l\~0.net  
# Also, if loaded from a USB device in this format it will not access your boot drive (system drive)  
title Balder (FreeDOS) Doesn't find System drives. Will read/edit boot device files  
find --set-root /balder10.img  
map --unsafe-boot /balder10.img (fd0)  
map --hook  
chainloader --force (fd0)+1  
rootnoverify (fd0)  

# Seems to work fine. I used both MBI and Unet and neither had an issue  
# The only time I did is if another ISO added or changed the BOOT FILES on the device ROOT  
# Suggested by Martin Andersson  
title DBAN 2.2.6 (Drive Nuker)  
find --set-root /dban-2.2.6_i586.iso  
map --mem /dban-2.2.6_i586.iso (hd32)  
map --hook  
root (hd32)  
chainloader (hd32)  

# Never failed unless other --system files-- existed on the device root to confuse it  
title Memtest86+  
find --set-root /mt410.iso  
map --mem /mt410.iso (hd32)  
map --hook  
root (hd32)  
chainloader (hd32)  

# Works for what I tried on the Menu, loads the screen and all  
title CloneMaxx (Disk Tools) No Vista Support -Says Never will  
find --set-root /clonemax.img  
map --unsafe-boot /clonemax.img (fd0)  
map --hook  
chainloader --force (fd0)+1  
rootnoverify (fd0)  

# Suggested by Deb -working Updated -TheZeDD  
title Partition Wizard 5.2 (Partition Tools)  
find --set-root /pwhe5.2.iso  
map /pwhe5.2.iso (hd32)  
map --hook  
root (hd32)  
chainloader (hd32)  

# This did not work for me. Period. I think you need to extract the ISO to the root and possibly more.  
title Parted Magic 5.3 (Partition Tools) If Extracted  
find --set-root /pmagic-5.3.iso  
map /pmagic-5.3.iso (hd32)  
map --hook  
root (hd32)  
configfile /boot/grub/grub4dos.lst  

# Stated to work for all PM v4.9-5.3 and maybe 4.x-5.4? If you copy your ISO to the root of your device.  
# Then simply edit these lines/file names as needed  
# Anytime you see this "/pmagic-5.3.iso" this must be "pathed" to the location of your .iso  
# e.g. If thats "/apps/tools/your.iso" then "find --set-root /apps/tools/your.iso"  
# Thats 2 folders/directories from ROOT and then your.iso/file ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) -TheZeDD  
title Parted Magic 5.3 Special Edition (Disk Tools)  
find --set-root /pmagic-5.3.iso   
map /pmagic-5.3.iso (hd32)  
map --hook  
root (hd32)  
chainloader (hd32)  

# DON'T DELETE THIS. This is different from previous Pmagic versions.  
# Simply drop pmagic5.5.iso on the root of your device.  
title Parted Magic 5.5 Special Edition (Disk Tools)  
find --set-root --ignore-floppies /pmagic-5.5.iso  
map --heads=0 --sectors-per-track=0 /pmagic-5.5.iso (0xff)  
map --hook  
root (0xff)  
chainloader (0xff)  

# This is the style that MBI uses and the way Pmagics site also says.   
# It does NOT work for me in my chosen setup! Probably needs to be extracted to the root.  
# Extracted meaning use something like 7zip and extract to the root or a folder on your device.  
title Parted Magic 5.1 (Partition Tools)  
find --set-root /pmagic-5.2.iso  
map /pmagic-5.2.iso (hd32)  
map --hook  
root (hd32)  
configfile /boot/grub/grub4dos.lst  

# PING - Partition Image Not Ghost  
# 40mb of diligent work, simple,   
# Allows imaging to a different partition on the same drive  
# Will image only the used sectors to spare image and drive space  
# PLUS supports compression in several ways to compact that further if needed  
title PING 3.00 Partition Image Not Ghost  
find --set-root /ping-3.00.iso  
map /ping-3.00.iso (hd32)  
map --hook  
root (hd32)  
chainloader (hd32)  

# Avira Rescue  
# I had trouble with this, it loads but goes no further then the main window  
title Avira Antivir Antivirus Rescue (Testing)  
find --set-root /Avira_rescue.iso  
map /Avira_rescue.iso (hd32)  
map --hook  
root (hd32)  
chainloader (hd32)  

# Working  
title Ultimate Boot CD 5.02  
find --set-root /ubcd502.iso  
map /ubcd502.iso (hd32)  
map --hook   
chainloader (hd32)  

# Hirens I didn't have to touch a thing for it to work, at least so far  
# Great tool with lots of options  
# Mini syslinux, Pmagic 4.11, Mini XP  
# Extract the HBCD-whichever.zip to a temp folder.   
# Then copy --HBCD-- folder to the root of your USB  
# Any other files outside of HBCD can nest on the root of the drive  
title Hiren's Boot CD ISO  
find --set-root /HBCD/menu.lst  
configfile /HBCD/menu.lst  

# Still testing unknown how well it works.  
# I really was looking forward to Bitdefender as you can update it previous to running.  
# But Bitdefender goes to a blank screen as if it might be working!?  
title AVG Rescue CD (Anti-Virus + Anti-Spyware)  
find --set-root /avg_arl_cd_en_90_100407.iso  
map /avg_arl_cd_en_90_100407.iso (hd32)  
map --hook  
chainloader (hd32)  

# As you can see, I am not using this right now if any because it doesnt work.   
# Kaspersky Rescue   
# title Kaspersky Rescue Antivirus Rescue (hd32 -unk)  
# find --set-root /rescue.iso  
# map /rescue.iso (hd32)  
# map --hook  
# root (hd32)  
# chainloader (hd32)  

# Kapsersky Rescue c/o Bharat   
# Creating a Root folder named rescue rename ISO to rescue.iso  
# title Kaspersky Rescue Disk 10 (Bharat Balegere - Agnipulse)  
# find --set-root /rescue/rescue.iso  
# map /rescue/rescue.iso (0xff) \|\| map --mem /rescue/rescue.iso (0xff)  
# map --hook  
# chainloader (0xff)  

# This is just my custom format is all...  
# Kaspersky Rescue testing - ISO on root of device  
title Kaspersky Rescue 2010 Updated (TZ 01 Working)  
find --set-root /kav_2010.iso  
map /kav_2010.iso (0xff) \|\| map --mem /kav_2010.iso (0xff)  
map --hook  
chainloader (0xff)  

# Kaspersky Rescue testing  
# title Kaspersky Rescue 2010 Updated (Testing 02)  
# find --set-root /rescue.iso  
# map /rescue.iso (0xff)  
# map --hook  
# root (0xff)  
# chainloader (0xff)  

# RIP Linux (Rescue Is Possible). Edit as needed.   
# Another Linux Rescue tool kit. May not be above Parted Magic but similar.  
title Riplinux 9.3  
find --set-root /RIPLinuX-9.3.iso  
map --heads=0 --sectors-per-track=0 /RIPLinuX-9.3.iso (0xff) \|\| map --heads=0 --sectors-per-track=0 --mem /RIPLinuX-9.3.iso (0xff)  
map --hook  
chainloader (0xff)  

# Working but did not allow files to be saved to a UFD (USB Flashmemory Device)  
title Kiwi 10.08 Debian-Ubuntu 10.04 (GNOME Desktop x86)  
find --set-root /Kiwi10.08.iso  
map /Kiwi10.08.iso (0xff)  
map --hook  
root (0xff)  
kernel /casper/vmlinuz file=/cdrom/preseed/ubuntu.seed boot=casper persistent iso-scan/filename=/Kiwi10.08.iso splash  
initrd /casper/initrd.lz  

# Tiny Core Linux version 3.1 or your version. Super small 10mb. Customize it to suit your needs  
# A bit limited at first unless your knowledgeable with Terminal or Networking/Upgrading   
# When using MBI (MultibootISO) users must rename the ISO to MBI's asking  
# Start Suggested by Erhan Sohail  
title TinyCore  
find --set-root /tinycore-current.iso  
map /tinycore-current.iso (0xff) \|\| map --mem /tinycore-current.iso (0xff)  
map --hook  
chainloader (0xff)  

# This is kind of a worthless program if the password and system have been setup correctly!  
title Offline NT Password \& Registy Editor (Loaded)  
find --set-root /cd080802.iso  
map /cd080802.iso (hd32)  
map --hook  
chainloader (hd32)  

title OphCrack XP 2.3.1 (XP Password Cracker)  
find --set-root /ophcrack-xp-livecd-2.3.1.iso  
map /ophcrack-xp-livecd-2.3.1.iso (0xff)

# Suggested by madprofessor //this file was another trivial pursuit to get working that

title Boot Clonezilla  
root (hd0,0)  
kernel /clonezilla/live/vmlinuz live-media-path=clonezilla/live bootfrom=/dev/sd boot=live union=aufs noprompt ocs_live_run="ocs-live-general" ocs_live_extra_param="" ocs_live_keymap="" ocs_live_batch="no" ocs_lang="" vga=791 ip=frommedia

# If You use MBI 2120 to help you to this one you'll understand more of how this all works

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> If any one has some good info for booting and loading from a UFD (USB Flash Drive) XP I would be greatful ![<_<](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/dry.png)
Would you be grateful to ALL those that have such info, or ONLY to those that besides having them are ALSO willing to share them with you? ![:mellow:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/mellow.png)  

> Really all I need is the Menu entry.... and I would guess regardless that it has to be extracted to the root of the drive. I would prefer a folder on the root of the drive and I am guessing then there is some ini that needs editing. Just trying to keep root as clean as possible.
That's what you think. ![<_<](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/dry.png)  

You probably need much more than that. :wink:  

Provided that you actually know how to have a "Full XP install" (which is not as easy as you might think) it's true you only need a menu.lst entry, but if you don't (as I suspect) you need many more than that.  

Start from links mentioned here:  
> A "Full XP on USB" is anyway something that is a bit more difficult to achieve, a "basic" PE should be much easier to achieve on USB, something like picoXP.  
>
> Installing XP on a USB stick may be daunting, you should read the tutorials by Dietmar (find links to them in his signature):  
> [http://www.911cd.net...showtopic=14181](http://www.911cd.net/forums//index.php?showtopic=14181 "External link")  
> The ngine.de "simplified" tutorial:  
> [http://www.ngine.de/article/id/8](http://www.ngine.de/article/id/8 "External link")  
> And try the automated way (simpler):  
> [http://www.usboot.org/tiki-index.php](http://www.usboot.org/tiki-index.php "External link")

And, then, this:  
[http://www.911cd.net...showtopic=22473](http://www.911cd.net/forums//index.php?showtopic=22473 "External link")  

The menu.lst entry is typically:  

```
title Full XP 

find --set-root /tagfile.tag

chainloader /ntldr
```

The tagfile.tag can be any UNIQUELY named file that is on the root of the same USB stick where the USB XP is installed, normally a simpler:  

```
title Full XP 

find --set-root /ntldr

chainloader /ntldr
```

is enough, but the use of a tagfile helps in avoiding possible problems with drive enumeration, where several drives do contain NTLDR in root.  

:smile:  
Wonko
